process.description: Large-scale tarps or shrink-wrap systems are installed to protect exposed areas from further rain damage. This is critical before any interior work begins.

process.title: Interior Water Mitigation
process.description: Any water that has entered is extracted, and drying equipment is deployed to prevent mold growth in affected areas.

process.title: Damage Documentation
process.description: Comprehensive documentation including photos, measurements, and damage reports is prepared for insurance claims.

process.title: Permanent Roof Repair Coordination
process.description: We coordinate with licensed roofing contractors to schedule permanent repairs, which may take weeks to months after major storms due to demand.

process.title: Interior Restoration
process.description: Once the roof is permanently repaired, interior damage to ceilings, walls, insulation, and other affected areas is fully restored.

faqs.question: How quickly can you respond after a hurricane?
faqs.answer: We pre-position resources before major storms and mobilize as soon as conditions are safe—typically within 24-48 hours of storm passage. Response times may be longer after major hurricanes due to access restrictions and widespread damage.

faqs.question: Will my insurance cover hurricane roof damage?
faqs.answer: Most Florida homeowner's policies cover hurricane damage, though many have separate hurricane deductibles (often 2-5% of the dwelling coverage). Document all damage thoroughly. We work directly with insurance adjusters to ensure proper claim documentation.

faqs.question: How long will a tarp protect my roof?
faqs.answer: Professional tarps typically provide 30-90 days of protection depending on installation method and weather conditions. Shrink-wrap systems can last 6-12 months. We monitor protected properties and address any issues promptly.

faqs.question: Why is there such a wait for permanent roof repairs after hurricanes?
faqs.answer: Major hurricanes damage thousands of roofs simultaneously, overwhelming contractor capacity. Quality roofers are booked months out. Emergency tarping protects your property during this wait. Be wary of storm-chasing contractors offering immediate work.

faqs.question: What should I do if I see roof damage after a hurricane?
faqs.answer: Document damage with photos from the ground (don't climb on a damaged roof). Place containers to catch any leaks inside. Call for emergency tarping immediately. Contact your insurance company to start the claims process.

faqs.question: Can any of my belongings be saved if rain got in?
faqs.answer: Quick action is key. Many items can be saved if dried quickly. However, items soaked by rain coming through a damaged roof—especially if sitting for days—may be beyond salvage. We assess contents and recommend cleaning or replacement.

storm.name: Wind Damage
storm.description: Wind damage restoration and property protection

bodyContent.overview:
Wind damage doesn't require a hurricane. South Florida experiences powerful thunderstorms year-round, and these storms frequently produce damaging straight-line winds, microbursts, and occasional tornadoes that can cause significant property damage.

Wind damage takes many forms: broken windows and doors, torn screens and awnings, damaged fencing and outdoor structures, compromised roof materials, and fallen trees or branches. Even without direct structural damage, wind can force rain into buildings through gaps it creates, causing secondary water damage.

What makes wind damage particularly challenging is that it often creates multiple points of vulnerability simultaneously. A single storm might blow out a window, lift roof shingles, and topple a fence—each requiring different restoration approaches and potentially allowing water intrusion from multiple directions.

Our wind damage restoration service addresses the full scope of storm damage, from emergency board-up and tarping to complete structural repairs. We secure your property immediately, prevent secondary damage, and restore everything the storm affected.
bodyContent.whyActFast: Wind damage creates openings that expose your property to weather and security risks. In Florida's climate, afternoon storms occur almost daily, meaning any unprotected opening will quickly allow water intrusion. Immediate board-up and tarping prevents compounding damage from subsequent weather events.
commonCauses: Microbursts creating sudden intense wind gusts
Flying debris propelled by high winds
Wind-driven rain forcing water through openings
preventionTips: Install impact-resistant windows or hurricane shutters
Secure loose outdoor items before storms
Trim trees and remove dead branches near structures
Ensure garage doors are wind-rated
Have roof inspected and secured properly
Install storm panels or shutters before hurricane season
Know how to quickly secure your property before storms
Keep emergency board-up materials on hand
warningSignals: Severe thunderstorm or tornado warnings for your area
Hurricane or tropical storm warnings
Sudden pressure drop and rapid wind increase
Sounds of breaking glass or impacts during storms
Visible debris flying during storms
Damage to fencing, screens, or outdoor structures after storms
Whistling sounds from windows or doors during wind
Water intrusion during or after storms

process.title: Emergency Board-Up
process.description: Broken windows, doors, and other openings are immediately secured with professional boarding or temporary barriers to prevent further damage and intrusion.

process.title: Roof Protection
process.description: Any roof damage is addressed with emergency tarping or shrink-wrapping to prevent water intrusion from subsequent rain.

process.title: Water Mitigation
process.description: If wind-driven rain has entered the property, water is extracted and drying equipment deployed to prevent mold growth.

process.title: Damage Assessment
process.description: Comprehensive assessment and documentation of all wind damage, including structural, roofing, window/door, and content damage.

process.title: Temporary Repairs
process.description: Temporary repairs are made to secure the property and restore functionality while permanent repairs are coordinated.

process.title: Complete Restoration
process.description: Windows, doors, roofing, siding, fencing, and any other damaged elements are permanently repaired or replaced.

faqs.question: What's the difference between hurricane damage and regular wind damage?
faqs.answer: Legally and for insurance purposes, hurricane damage occurs when the National Weather Service declares a hurricane. This matters because many policies have separate, higher hurricane deductibles. Severe thunderstorm wind damage is usually covered under your regular deductible.

faqs.question: How quickly can you board up broken windows?
faqs.answer: We respond to emergency board-up calls quickly—typically within a few hours during normal conditions. After major storms, demand is high, and we prioritize based on severity and security risk. Call immediately to get in the queue.

faqs.question: Will my insurance cover wind damage?
faqs.answer: Most homeowner's policies cover wind damage. Coverage includes structural damage, content damage, and often additional living expenses if your home is uninhabitable. Document everything and contact your insurance promptly.

faqs.question: Can wind damage allow water into my home?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Wind-driven rain can force water through the smallest openings, and any structural damage wind creates—broken windows, lifted shingles, damaged doors—allows rain entry. In Florida, this secondary water damage is often worse than the initial wind damage.

faqs.question: Should I try to cover a broken window myself?
faqs.answer: If you can do so safely, covering a broken window with plywood or plastic provides temporary protection. However, professional board-up is more secure and weather-resistant. Don't attempt to cover openings if there are continued storm risks or if access is dangerous.

faqs.question: How do I know if wind damaged my roof?
faqs.answer: After storms, look for missing or displaced shingles/tiles, debris in gutters, granules from asphalt shingles, or visible damage from the ground. Inside, check for new water stains or leaks. A professional inspection after significant storms is recommended.

storm.name: Tree Damage
storm.description: Tree damage cleanup and property restoration

bodyContent.overview:
South Florida's lush tropical landscape is beautiful, but those mature trees can become dangerous projectiles during storms. Fallen trees and large branches cause some of the most dramatic and severe property damage we see, often crashing through roofs, smashing vehicles, destroying fencing, and completely crushing outdoor structures.

Tree damage creates unique restoration challenges. The immediate priority is stabilizing the structure—a tree on your roof represents ongoing risk of collapse, continued water intrusion, and potential secondary damage with each passing hour. Only after the tree is safely removed can the full extent of structural damage be assessed.

Tree impacts often cause complex damage patterns: roof penetrations allow water entry, falling debris damages multiple areas, and the weight of the tree can compromise structural framing. Even after tree removal, extensive repairs are typically needed to roof, ceiling, walls, and sometimes the entire structural system.

Our tree damage restoration team coordinates every aspect of recovery—from emergency tree removal and tarping to structural repairs and interior restoration—getting your property secure and restored as efficiently as possible.
bodyContent.whyActFast: A tree on your roof creates constant risk of further collapse and continuous water intrusion. Every rain event—and in Florida, that's almost daily—causes additional interior damage. Emergency stabilization and tarping must happen immediately, before permanent repairs can even be assessed.
commonCauses: Lightning strikes splitting or felling trees
Improper tree maintenance leaving weak structure
Trees planted too close to structures
preventionTips: Have trees professionally assessed annually for health and stability
Remove dead or dying trees near structures
Trim branches that overhang roofs or are within falling distance
Know the species—some trees are more wind-resistant than others
Maintain proper tree structure with regular pruning
Don't top trees—it creates weak, dangerous regrowth
Consider tree removal if roots are compromising foundation
After storms, have damaged trees evaluated by an arborist
warningSignals: Trees leaning after storms or heavy rain
Visible root upheaval or soil movement at tree base
Dead branches or limbs in tree canopy
Fungal growth or decay on trunk or roots
Cracks or splits in trunk or major branches
Trees with multiple trunks showing separation
Significant branch loss creating unbalanced canopy
Trees with compromised root systems from construction

process.title: Emergency Stabilization
process.description: We coordinate emergency tree removal to eliminate the ongoing risk of further collapse. Structural supports may be installed if needed for safety.

process.title: Emergency Tarping
process.description: Once the tree is removed, damaged roof areas are immediately tarped or covered to prevent water intrusion.

process.title: Structural Assessment
process.description: With the tree removed, we assess the full extent of structural damage including roof, framing, walls, and other affected areas.

process.title: Water Mitigation
process.description: Any water that entered during the tree impact or before tarping is extracted, and affected areas are professionally dried.

process.title: Debris Removal & Cleanup
process.description: All debris from the tree and damaged building materials is removed from the property.

process.title: Complete Restoration
process.description: Structural repairs are completed including roof reconstruction, framing repair, drywall, painting, and any other damaged elements.

faqs.question: What should I do if a tree falls on my house?
faqs.answer: Evacuate immediately if anyone is inside near the impact area—structural collapse can occur. Stay clear of the damaged area and downed power lines. Call 911 if there's immediate danger. Then contact your insurance company and a restoration professional for emergency response.

faqs.question: Is tree damage covered by homeowner's insurance?
faqs.answer: Yes, most policies cover tree damage to your dwelling and structures. Coverage typically includes tree removal, structural repairs, and interior damage. Your policy may also cover debris removal costs. Document all damage thoroughly for your claim.

faqs.question: How quickly can you respond to tree damage emergencies?
faqs.answer: We respond to tree damage calls as quickly as possible—typically within hours during normal conditions. After major storms with widespread tree damage, we prioritize based on severity and ongoing risk. Call immediately to ensure prompt response.

faqs.question: Should I try to remove the tree myself?
faqs.answer: No—tree removal from structures is extremely dangerous and requires specialized equipment and expertise. Improper removal can cause additional structural damage or serious injury. Leave emergency tree removal to professionals with proper training and insurance.

faqs.question: How long does tree damage restoration take?
faqs.answer: Timeline depends on damage severity. Minor tree impacts might be restored in 2-4 weeks. Significant structural damage—trees crashing through roofs into living spaces—can require months of repair. We provide detailed timelines after assessment.

faqs.question: What if the tree came from my neighbor's property?
faqs.answer: In most cases, your own homeowner's insurance covers tree damage to your property regardless of where the tree originated—unless the neighbor was negligent (knew the tree was dangerous and did nothing). This is a common insurance scenario.
